Comment: Within the NP, adjectives, along with number words, follow the head (which is mostly a noun).If the NP is in argument or predicative form, both the head and the adjective agree in gender, number and form. See (Ciucci_2019, p. 8).'

Morphemic: tɨk-iya õr ɨti-ch koot-ɨt / õr ɨtɨ-lo koot-uwo.
Translation: I buy a soft pillow / soft pillows.
Comment: Within the NP, adjectives, along with number words, follow the head (which is mostly a noun).If the NP is in argument or predicative form, both the head and the adjective agree in gender, number and form. See (Ciucci_2019, p. 8).'

Translation: S/he blesses her/him. (lit: S/he says words good for her/him.)'
Comment: It is not very common, but it is documented. The adpositional phrase follows the noun.'
There is no verb ‘be’ in Chamacoco. The predicative function of nouns and adjective is expressed by a dedicated predicative form (PRED).' (Comments from Ciucci)

The original contrast between predicative form and argument form is disappearing in Chamacoco. One of the consequences is that the argument form can also carry out predicative function. See (Ciucci_2019, p. 3). Ciucci (2019, p. 3) also states that the non-verbal predicative forms carry more morphological material than the same lexical elements in non-predicative function.'

Translation: This thing is good for me.
Comment: The {adpositional} phrase always occurs after the adjective.'

Translation: The room is full of many things.
Comment: Although it is not frequent, an adjective can be found as possessor or possessed within a possessive NP. Here the possessed is the invariable adjective ‘full’. See (Ciucci_2019, p. 10). '

Translation: I met a liberal man who is generous.
Comment: Relative clauses are often used to avoid sequences of adjectives within the same NP.

Translation: The black dog is running. (lit: The dog which is black is running.)'
Comment: Ciucci (2019, p. 10) states that relative clauses are introduced by the subordinator uje, but it can be omitted.'

Translation: I do not forget that woman whom I saw.

Morphemic: T-itɨm olak par uje erze pukuhnin-o õr eyucha nẽhe ese oyayuwa-t uje loshɨp-o de-yo.
Gloss: 1SG-tell 2PL SUB SUB that.PL child-M.PL 3PL 3.remember FUT that.M.SG giant_anaconda-M.SG.AF SUB 3-eat animal-M.PL big-M.PL
Translation: I tell you so that these children will remind of this anaconda which eats big animals.
I buy clothes for the cold.
Comment: Chamacoco has a limited number of adpositions, thus, such structure is less frequent. The adpositional phrase always follows the noun. (Comments from Ciucci)

Translation: The man sees the giant anaconda in the river.

Morphemic: loshi-yo tre de-yo kahr-o hn ɨhɨ̃r-tso
Gloss: fish-M.PL three big-M.PL yellow-M.PL and beautiful-M.PL
